[[Paul Shaman]] | known_for = [[Anderson–Darling test]], [[Anderson–Bahadur algorithm]] | prizes = | religion = | footnotes = }} '''Theodore Wilbur Anderson''' (born June 5, 1918) is an [[United States|American]] [[mathematician]] and [[statistician]] who has specialized in the analysis of [[multivariate statistics|multivariate data]]. Born in [[Minneapolis]], Minnesota,http://www.iwms08.ipt.pt/anderson.htm he was awarded a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] in 1946.{{cite web|title=Search Results: Theodore Anderson|url=http://www.gf.org/fellows/results?query=Theodore+Anderson&lower_bound=1925&upper_bound=2011&competition=ALL&fellowship_category=ALL&x=0&y=0|work=John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|accessdate=18 April 2011}} He was on the faculty of [[Columbia University]] from 1946 until moving to [[Stanford University]] in 1967, becoming Emeritus Professor in 1988. He served as Editor of ''[[Annals of Mathematical Statistics]]'' from 1950 to 1952. He was elected President of the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]] in 1962. He was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1974.{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780-2010: Chapter A|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterA.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=18 April 2011}} Anderson's 1958{{cite book|author1=Täonu Kollo|author2=Dietrich von Rosen|title=Advanced Multivariate Statistics with Matrices|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=27mA99VQTi4C&pg=PR13|accessdate=17 June 2013|date=1 January 2005|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4020-3419-0|pages=13–}} textbook,'' An Introduction to Multivariate Analysis'',{{cite book | last = Anderson | first = T.W. | title = An introduction to multivariate statistical analysis | publisher = John Wiley and Sons | location = New York | year = 2004 | edition = 3rd | isbn = 9789812530967 }} educated a generation of theorists and applied statisticians; Anderson's book emphasizes [[hypothesis testing]] via [[likelihood ratio test]]s and the properties of [[Statistical power|power function]]s: [[admissible decision rule|Admissibility]], [[bias of an estimator|unbiasedness]] and [[monotonicity]].{{cite journal|doi =10.2307/2289251|title =Review: Contemporary Textbooks on Multivariate Statistical Analysis: A Panoramic Appraisal and Critique|first9 =K.
